alert.note: Alert for Delaware (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 10 at 1:13AM EST until January 10 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Pennsylvania... Chester Creek Near Chester affecting Delaware County. For the Chester Creek...including Chester...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Chester Creek near Chester. * WHEN...Until late this morning. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, The creek floods adjacent open land. At 10.5 feet, Flood damage, adjacent to the creek, begins in the city of Chester. At 11.5 feet, Parker and Kerlin Streets flood. The 600 to 1300 blocks of Parker Street are subject to evacuations. The 1300-1400 blocks of Kerlin Street are also subject to evacuations. At 12.5 feet, The Parker Manor section of Chester is subject to evacuations. At 13.0 feet, Chester Creek Road floods in Brookhaven Borough. Closures are possible between Dutton Mill Road and Bridgewater Road. Mt. Alverno Road between Middletown and Aston is closed due to flooding. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:47 AM EST Wednesday the stage was 12.4 feet and falling. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 12:47 AM EST Wednesday was 12.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early this morning and continue falling to 3.1 feet late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.2 feet on 04/02/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Stream Fld Observed Fcsts (1 am) Crest Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Stg Time Date Chester Creek Chester 8.0 12.4 Wed 12 a 3.2 MSG Crested & Falling &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Turn around...don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/phi. The next statement will be issued this morning at 900 AM EST.
